statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description:
Kevin Garnett scored 21 points, and Rasho Nesterovic had 12 points and 10 rebounds Wednesday night to lead
Minnesota to a 95-64 victory over the Los Angeles Clippers.
article.headline: Clips shoot 32 percent, fall by 31 points
article.linkText: Clippers score just 64, get routed by T-Wolves
article.story:
LOS ANGELES (AP) -- Kevin Garnett liked the way the Minnesota Timberwolves started and the way they kept going on their way to holding the Los Angeles Clippers to their fewest points in 31 years. Garnett scored 21 points as Minnesota beat the Clippers 95-64 on Wednesday, the franchise's lowest point total since 1972 -- and second lowest ever. "We did a great job of executing for 48 minutes, both our teams that came into the game. By that I mean the bench and the starting lineup. The starters set the tone,'' Garnett said. The Minnesota starters outscored the cold-shooting Clippers 23-13 in the first quarter, and the Timberwolves were in control the rest of the game on the way to their most lopsided win of the season. The Clippers' 64 points were one more than the franchise record low in a 91-63 loss to Milwaukee when they were the Buffalo Braves. Many in the crowd of 15,838 booed the Clippers throughout the loss to Minnesota. Los Angeles coach Alvin Gentry said the booing was deserved and that the Clippers' performance was embarrassing. "That was ridiculous. It should be embarrassing to everybody involved. It's an embarrassment to the fans who paid their money to come in here and see it,'' Gentry said after the Clippers lost for the eighth time in 10 games. "It was an embarrassment to management, it's an embarrassment to our owners, and it should be an embarrassment to the players -- and the coaches. Nobody should be immune from this. It's absolutely embarrassing -- and the fans deserve to boo something like that.'' Minnesota's winning margin was its largest ever against the Clippers, who shot just 32 percent from the floor. As time was running out, Minnesota coach Flip Saunders instructed his players to hold the ball and not shoot. "We played extremely well and extremely hard,'' Saunders said. Rasho Nesterovic had 12 points and 10 rebounds for Minnesota, which held a double-digit lead all the way after the first quarter. The Timberwolves were especially effective defensively up front, limiting Los Angeles center Michael Olowokandi to three shots and four points, and Elton Brand to 12 points. Olowokandi was frustrated. "I don't see it getting better. Let's not fool ourselves,'' he said. "We can talk about being optimistic, but if you don't address the real problem, it's not going to get better -- unless we just magically start making our outside shots. "It's that simple. Everyone is searching for deeper answers. But that's what I see. The coach might have a different viewpoint.'' The Clippers shot 26.3 percent in the first quarter and fell behind by 10, although the Timberwolves shot just 26.9 percent. It didn't get any better for Los Angeles, which was outscored 27-11 in the fourth quarter. Corey Maggette had 20 points for Los Angeles, and Lamar Odom had 13 points and nine rebounds. Minnesota won for the fourth time in five games and avenged a loss to the Clippers last month. Minnesota was up 68-53 heading into the fourth quarter, and its biggest lead was 31 points at the end of the game. Clippers rookie guard Marko Jaric, back after missing eight games with a sprained ankle, was ejected late in the game after he kept jawing at Garnett. Jaric scored just one point in 15 minutes.

Game notes
Minnesota guard Troy Hudson, who sprained his left ankle early in Minnesota's 89-75 win Monday, did not play against Los Angeles. ... The Clippers activated Jaric and put forward Tremaine Fowlkes on the injured list with a strained right shoulder. Jaric missed eight games after spraining his left ankle on Dec. 27. Fowlkes scored 15 points and held Garnett to just five points and three rebounds in the second half of the Clippers' 104-88 victory on Dec. 7.
